hints_html:
The linear approximation to a multivariable function \(f\)(x,y) at a point (x,y) = (a,b) is given by L(x,y) where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x,y) = f(a,b) + f_{x}(a,b)(x - a) + f_{y}(a,b)(y - b)\end{aligned}\]

where the subscripts denote partial differentiation with respect to the given variable.

sols_html:
The linear approximation to a multivariable function \(f\)(x,y) at a point (x,y) = (a,b) is given by L(x,y) where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x,y) = f(a,b) + f_{x}(a,b)(x - a) + f_{y}(a,b)(y - b)\end{aligned}\]

where the subscripts denote partial differentiation with respect to the given variable. In this case the partial derivatives of \(f(x,y) = \ln(4x^{2} + y^{2})\) are

\[\begin{aligned} f_{x}(x,y) = \frac{8x}{4x^{2} + y^{2}}, \quad f_{y}(x,y) = \frac{2y}{4x^{2} + y^{2}}.\end{aligned}\]

and we wish to approximate \(f\) near (x,y) = (0,1). Hence the linear approximation we seek is:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x,y) &= \ln(1) + 0\cdot(x - 0) + 2(y - 1) \\ &= 2y - 2\end{aligned}\]

Using the linear approximation, we can estimate the value of \(f\)(0.1,1.2) as

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}f(0.1,1.2) \approx L(0.1,1.2) = 0.4}.\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}z=f(x,y)=\ln(4x^2+y^2)\end{aligned}\]

Use a linear approximation of the function z=f(x,y) at (0,1) to estimate f(0.1,1.2).
